title: What were the experiments on somnambulism and their results, as described by Dr. Marc Dufour in a letter?
first_phrase: In this text, Doctor Marc Dufour reflects on experiments conducted by German professors on magnetic sleep, where subjects were placed in an extreme state of rigidity and unconsciousness. When brought back to consciousness, they had no memory of what was done during their state of sleep, but could recall events from the first sleep when placed back in it. Dufour notes a discrepancy between his findings and those of the German professors regarding the ability to repeat words, song, or laughter under magnetic sleep. He concludes by expressing gratitude and acknowledging that further research is needed to understand the exact nature of magnetic sleep.

J’ai vu un expérimentateur paralyser les muscles maxillaires après avoir fermé la bouche du sujet, et lui demander ensuite son nom.
last_phrase: In conclusion, it is important to differentiate between actual forgetting and the physical inability to speak. A subject may know the answer, but their muscles may be paralyzed, leading to the inability to respond. It is crucial to observe and analyze the situation carefully to avoid misunderstandings.
